Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A house has structural wood damage from termites, and the carpenter needs to provide an urgent repair plan
Story: My phone buzzed again, the screen lighting up with another message from Mom. She wanted to know if I’d eaten, if I was warm enough, if I’d remembered to call Auntie about her birthday. I’d always made it a point to reply quickly, to keep our daily conversations going—she said it made her feel close to me, even though I’d moved out years ago. But right now, I was kneeling in the crawlspace of a client’s house, flashlight in one hand, poking at beams that crumbled under my touch. The termite damage was worse than I’d thought, and the homeowner was hovering anxiously, waiting for my assessment. I knew I needed to focus, to draft a repair plan before the damage got any worse. But my phone kept buzzing, each vibration a reminder of my promise to my parents. I felt torn, the weight of their expectations pressing against the urgency of my work. My mind raced, caught between the comfort of family and the responsibility of my craft, unsure which demand to answer first.
